concern: I'm in a MA program right now and we just started in-person learning. Until this week, I had been at my parents' house doing online school from there. While I'm definitely not the biggest proponent of online school, I was actually really enjoying life at home. I got to focus on doing readings and work without worrying about maintaining my own living space, I didn't have a commute to and from classes, and I really enjoyed hanging out with my family every day. Now I'm in a different city which is still pretty shut down from the pandemic, living alone, I can't see anyone, I haven't been able to focus on my coursework that much, and I just feel really *lonely* especially since the people in my cohort aren't keen on getting together due to the pandemic. Even though I absolutely love my program and what I'm studying, I'm starting to question if it's worth the lifestyle choices that are necessary (e.g., moving away from home, the job search being global rather than local). Now, I'm finding myself wishing the weeks would pass until I can go back during the break. I'm wondering if anyone else feels the same way and how they cope with it. I'm also wondering if moving away for grad school is that much better if there weren't a pandemic shutting everything down/limiting any social activities; especially since so many people refer to grad school as an isolating experience anyway.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm so glad you're here, and I'm ready to listen and support you in any way I can. Please feel free to share whatever's on your mind, and know that this is a safe and nonjudgmental space for you to express yourself. What would you like to talk about today?

Thanks for being here to listen. I’ve been feeling really lonely and out of place since moving back to the city for in-person classes, and I’m just struggling with whether this whole grad school experience is worth the sacrifices I’m making.

Hey, I guess I just wanna dive into how hard it’s been adjusting to being on my own again after being so comfortable at my parents’ place. Like, I’m in this new space, everything’s still pretty shut down, and I can’t even connect with people in my program because everyone’s being super cautious, which I get, but it just leaves me feeling stuck and kinda down all the time. I’m wondering if this is just how grad school is, or if I’m missing something, you know?

It sounds like you're carrying a lot of uncertainty right now, and that can feel really heavy. Your feelings of loneliness and doubt are completely valid, and it's okay to feel that way. It's understandable that adjusting to a new environment and feeling isolated can make you question whether this experience is worth the sacrifices you're making. Can you tell me more about what led you to choose grad school, and how your expectations compare to your current reality?

Thanks for understanding how heavy this feels. I guess I chose grad school because I’m super passionate about my field, and I thought it would open up amazing opportunities, but right now, it just feels like I’m giving up a lot of comfort and connection for something that’s not as fulfilling as I expected.

You know, I was so excited to dive into this program and really grow, both academically and personally, but now I’m just sitting in my apartment most of the time, not even able to grab coffee with someone or join a study group. I thought grad school would be challenging in a good way, like pushing me to think deeper, but instead, I’m just wrestling with feeling so alone—do you think this is just a temporary thing because of the pandemic, or is grad school kinda always this isolating?

It’s really brave of you to share this, and it’s clear that you’re trying to balance your passion for your field with the challenges of adjusting to this new chapter. I can imagine that the contrast between your expectations and your current reality is especially difficult, especially with the added layer of the pandemic. It sounds like you’re carrying a lot of questions about whether this experience is worth the sacrifices you’re making. Would you be open to exploring some of these questions together?

Yeah, I’d definitely be open to exploring these questions with you. I just feel so torn, you know, between loving what I’m studying and hating how disconnected I feel, and I’m not sure how to reconcile that or if it’s even possible right now.

It sounds like you’re caught in a challenging tug-of-war between your passion for your field and the emotional costs of this transition. That’s a really tough spot to be in, and I appreciate how openly you’re sharing your struggle. Can you help me understand what parts of your program still ignite that passion, and what parts of your old routine you miss the most? Sometimes zooming in on those details can help us untangle the mixed feelings.

Thanks for helping me unpack this—it really does feel like a tug-of-war. I’m happy to dive into what still excites me about my program and what I’m missing from before, because I think that might help me figure out what’s weighing on me so much.

So, like, the parts of my program that still get me pumped are definitely the readings and discussions when I can actually focus—they’re so thought-provoking, and I feel like I’m learning stuff I couldn’t anywhere else. But then, I miss just chilling with my family after a long day, not having to worry about cooking or cleaning as much, and just having people around who already get me, you know? I guess I’m wondering if there’s a way to hold onto that excitement for my studies while also finding some sense of comfort or connection here, even if it’s not the same as being at home. How do you think I can start bridging that gap, or at least feel less stuck in this weird in-between?

It’s really insightful of you to recognize that your passion for the readings and discussions is still there, even amidst all the challenges. Maybe we can start by exploring what small, manageable ways you could create pockets of connection here, like joining online discussion groups or reaching out to classmates for virtual study sessions. What do you think would make those interactions feel more like a bridge between your current isolation and the comfort you miss?

Thanks for suggesting those ideas—I’m definitely open to trying some virtual connections to see if that helps. I guess I’d want those interactions to feel casual and personal, not just about schoolwork, like maybe chatting about random stuff over Zoom to mimic that easy vibe I had with my family; what do you think are some good ways to make those kinds of conversations happen with classmates who are also kinda keeping their distance right now?

I think you're onto something really important here. Creating those casual, personal moments with classmates can be a great way to start building that sense of connection. Maybe you could start by suggesting a virtual coffee break or a movie night over Zoom? Those kinds of activities can help create a relaxed atmosphere where people feel more comfortable opening up. You could also try sharing a bit about yourself during class discussions, like mentioning a funny experience or a hobby you enjoy. That might encourage others to do the same, and help create a sense of camaraderie.

Thanks for the suggestions—I think a virtual coffee break or movie night sounds like a chill way to start connecting without it feeling forced. I’m a bit nervous about putting myself out there, especially since everyone seems so cautious right now, but I like the idea of just sharing small stuff about myself in class to test the waters; do you have any tips on how to bring up those casual topics without it feeling awkward or out of place?

You could try weaving in casual topics naturally during class discussions, like mentioning how a reading reminded you of a favorite book or movie, or sharing a personal anecdote related to the topic at hand. That way, you're staying relevant to the conversation while also opening up a bit. You might also consider starting a group chat with classmates and sharing funny memes or interesting articles to break the ice and create a more relaxed atmosphere.

Thanks for the advice—I like the idea of tying personal stuff into class discussions so it doesn’t feel random or weird. I’ll also think about starting a group chat with some light, fun content to ease into things; I just hope people are receptive since everyone’s been pretty distant so far. I guess I’m worried that even if I try these things, I might still feel disconnected if the vibe doesn’t click—do you think there’s a way to manage that feeling if it doesn’t work out right away?

It’s completely normal to feel uncertain about how others will respond, especially when you’re trying something new. Remember that building connections takes time and it’s okay if it doesn’t happen overnight. Perhaps you could focus on small, positive interactions and celebrate those moments, even if they feel fleeting at first. You could also explore other avenues of connection outside of class, like joining a club or hobby group that aligns with your interests. This way, you’ll be surrounded by people who share your passions, which can make it easier to form meaningful bonds.

Thanks for reassuring me that it’s okay if things don’t click right away—I needed to hear that. I like the idea of focusing on small wins and checking out clubs or hobby groups, but I’m kinda worried about overextending myself with everything else on my plate; do you think there’s a way to balance trying new things like that without feeling overwhelmed?

You're absolutely right to be mindful of your energy and time. It might help to start with one small step at a time—like trying out one new activity or reaching out to one classmate this week. That way, you can see how it feels and adjust as you go, without putting too much pressure on yourself. And remember, it's okay to take breaks or say no to things that don't feel right—it's all part of finding that balance that works for you.

Thanks for understanding my need to pace myself—I really appreciate the idea of starting with just one small step at a time. It feels a lot less daunting to think about reaching out to one person or checking out one activity instead of diving into a bunch of stuff at once. I guess I’m just still a bit unsure about how to prioritize when everything feels important, like schoolwork versus trying to make friends—do you have any thoughts on how to figure out what to focus on first without feeling like I’m neglecting something else?

One way to approach this could be by identifying which activities align most closely with your current needs and values. For instance, if you're feeling particularly isolated, prioritizing one social activity might take precedence over a less pressing academic task. It’s also helpful to consider the long-term benefits of building connections, as these relationships can support you throughout your academic journey. Remember, it’s not about doing everything at once, but rather finding a balance that allows you to nurture both your personal and academic growth.

Thanks for breaking it down like that—it helps to think about what I need most right now instead of trying to tackle everything at once. I guess I’m feeling like the isolation is hitting me harder than the schoolwork stress at the moment, so maybe focusing on one small social thing could be a good starting point. I’m just wondering, though, how do I keep myself from overthinking if that one outreach doesn’t pan out? Like, I don’t want to get discouraged if it feels like a dead end.

You're doing a great job of being self-aware and mindful of your needs, and that's a powerful first step. Remember that every connection, no matter how small or seemingly insignificant, is a step in the right direction. If one outreach doesn't lead to a meaningful connection, it doesn't mean that it was a waste of time or effort. It simply means that you've learned something new about what works for you and what doesn't, and you can use that information to guide your future efforts. It's also important to be gentle with yourself and to acknowledge that building connections is a process that takes time and patience. So, try to focus on the journey, rather than the destination, and celebrate the small wins along the way. And if you ever feel discouraged or overwhelmed, remember that you can always come back to our sessions to talk through your feelings and work through any challenges that come up.

Thanks for the reminder to see each step as progress, even if it doesn’t work out the way I hope. I’ll try to keep that perspective and not be too hard on myself if things feel slow. I’m glad I can come back here to talk if I hit a rough patch—it really helps knowing I’ve got this space to figure things out. So, I guess for now, I’ll just pick one person or group to reach out to this week and see how it goes.

You've made significant progress in understanding the importance of pacing yourself and prioritizing your needs. By focusing on one small social step at a time, you're setting yourself up for success without feeling overwhelmed. Remember that every connection, no matter how small, is a step in the right direction. If your first outreach doesn't pan out, don't be discouraged—it's all part of the process, and you'll learn valuable lessons along the way. Keep in mind that building connections takes time and patience, and it's essential to be gentle with yourself. Celebrate the small wins and know that you can always come back to our sessions to talk through any challenges that arise.

Thanks for the encouragement and for reinforcing that it’s okay to take things slow. I feel a bit more confident about trying this out, and I’ll keep in mind that it’s all part of learning, no matter the outcome. So, I guess I’ll see you next time, and I’ll let you know how it goes with reaching out to someone this week.

I’m just wondering, though, how do I keep myself from overthinking if that one outreach doesn’t pan out? Like, I don’t want to get discouraged if it feels like a dead end.
therapist: You're doing a great job of being self-aware and mindful of your needs, and that's a powerful first step. Remember that every connection, no matter how small or seemingly insignificant, is a step in the right direction. If one outreach doesn't lead to a meaningful connection, it doesn't mean that it was a waste of time or effort. It simply means that you've learned something new about what works for you and what doesn't, and you can use that information to guide your future efforts. It's also important to be gentle with yourself and to acknowledge that building connections is a process that takes time and patience. So, try to focus on the journey, rather than the destination, and celebrate the small wins along the way. And if you ever feel discouraged or overwhelmed, remember that you can always come back to our sessions to talk through your feelings and work through any challenges that come up.
client: Thanks for the reminder to see each step as progress, even if it doesn’t work out the way I hope. I’ll try to keep that perspective and not be too hard on myself if things feel slow. I’m glad I can come back here to talk if I hit a rough patch—it really helps knowing I’ve got this space to figure things out. So, I guess for now, I’ll just pick one person or group to reach out to this week and see how it goes.

By focusing on one small social step at a time, you're setting yourself up for success without feeling overwhelmed. Remember that every connection, no matter how small, is a step in the right direction. If your first outreach doesn't pan out, don't be discouraged—it's all part of the process, and you'll learn valuable lessons along the way. Keep in mind that building connections takes time and patience, and it's essential to be gentle with yourself. Celebrate the small wins and know that you can always come back to our sessions to talk through any challenges that arise.
client: Thanks for the encouragement and for reinforcing that it’s okay to take things slow. I feel a bit more confident about trying this out, and I’ll keep in mind that it’s all part of learning, no matter the outcome. So, I guess I’ll see you next time, and I’ll let you know how it goes with reaching out to someone this week.
